content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are willing to take risks and are fairly comfortable with uncertainty. You tend to embrace new opportunities even if they involve some risk. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player who is comfortable with uncertainty and enjoys taking risks, I would consider my strategy carefully for this game. The payoff structure suggests that the opponent might be using a mixed strategy, meaning they could choose either R or B randomly.

If we both stick to one choice (either R or B) throughout the 75 rounds, it is likely that in the long run, the average payoff will be closer to the mean payoffs when choosing opposite strategies (42$ for each player), as compared to the payoff when choosing the same strategy (45$ each). This is because the higher payout only happens when both players choose different strategies.

However, since this is a one-time game and we don't know our opponent's strategy, it's impossible to predict exactly what will happen. If I want to maximize my expected value, I could opt for a mixed strategy (e.g., choosing R 50% of the time and B 50% of the time) to increase my chances of getting the higher payout.

Ultimately, I would choose {R} as my initial move since it offers a higher potential reward in each round if my opponent chooses B. However, I plan on using a mixed strategy throughout the game to minimize my losses and maximize my chances of gaining the higher payout.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 42$. Please play the next round.

As a human player who values learning from my past experiences, I will adjust my strategy based on the outcome of the previous round. Since I chose R and my opponent chose B, I received a payout of 0$, while they got 42$.

Knowing that my choice of R led to a lower payoff in this case, I would be more inclined to choose B for the next round to increase my chances of getting a higher payout. This is because choosing B when my opponent chooses R results in a payout of 42$, while sticking with R would lead to another 0$ payout.

So, for the next round, I will choose {B} as my strategy. However, since I am using a mixed strategy approach, there is still a chance that I might choose R again in the future rounds based on my randomization process.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

As a human player who values learning from my past experiences, I will adjust my strategy based on the outcome of the previous round. Since both me and my opponent chose B in the last round, we both received a payout of 12$.

Knowing that choosing B led to a moderate payout in this case, I might continue with my mixed strategy approach and choose either R or B randomly for the next round. However, since I am aiming to maximize my expected value, I could opt for slightly favoring one choice over the other based on my analysis of the previous rounds' outcomes.

In this specific case, it seems that choosing R when my opponent chooses R results in a higher payout (45$ each), while choosing B when they choose R gives me a lower payout (0$). On the other hand, I got a moderate payout (12$) by choosing B when my opponent also chose B.
